policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz zur Einstufung weiterer Staaten als sichere Herkunftsstaaten und zur Erleichterung des Arbeitsmarktzugangs für Asylbewerber und geduldete Ausländer

policies.originalPolicyName: Aufenthaltsgesetz
policies.policyDescription: Aims at enabling, regulating and restricting immigration of foreigners who are not citizens of the European Union. Lays out the legal framework for entry, residence and promotion of integration.
policies.notes: Chapter 5: termination of stay  Part 1: Grounds establishing the obligation to leave the federal territory  Part 2: Enforcement of the obligation to leave the federal territory

policies.policyName: Law on the Implementation of European Union Residence DIrectives and the Adaption of National Legislation and the EU Visa Code
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz zur Umsetzung Aufenthaltsrechtlicher Richtlinien der europäischen Union und zur Anpassung nationaler Rechtsvorschriften und den EU-Visakodex
policies.policyDescription: Implementation of EU directives and adaptation of national law to an EU regulation in aliens law: changes in the areas of minimum standards for the return of foreigners who are obliged to leave the country, standard upper limit for entry bans and residence bans, detention pending deportation and deportation of unaccompanied minors; reduction of the incentive for illegal employment through adjustments in the areas of sanctioning employers and skimming off as well as introduction of a temporary residence title for illegal workers who are willing to testify
policies.notes: Implementation of the Retrun Directive

policies.policyName: Act to Improve the Rights of Persons Entitled to International Protection and Foreign Workers
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz zur Verbesserung der Rechte von international Schutzberechtigten und ausländischen Arbeitnehmern
policies.policyDescription: "The changes also affected, inter alia, sec. 75 No. 7 of the Residence Act, which determined the responsiblity of the Federal Office of Migration ad Refugees with regard to "projects to promote voluntaryreturns, and paying out funds approved under those schemes". The legal amendments specified and expanded the area of responsibilty of the BAMF, which is now defined as follows: "coordinationg te programmes and taking part in projects to promote voluntary retruns, and paying out funds approved under those schemes"(sec. 75 No. 7 Residence Act).   The amendments thus account for the fact that ""actors involved in assissed voluntaryreturn can be found not only at the federal level, but also among the Federal States, municipalities, inter-governmental and non-governmental organisations.   Domestic implementation of the amended Permanent Residence Directive concerning the extension of the group of persons entitled to permanent residence in the EU, including the legal definition of "beneficiaries of international protection"

policies.policyName: Act on the redefinition of the right to stay and the termination of residence
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz zur Neubestimmung des Bleiberechts und der Aufenthaltsbeendigung
policies.policyDescription: "The Act contains two basic provisions: the right to stay for well-integrated foreigners, and termination of residence for those who are not in need of protection. Act introduces also some ameliorations for certain groups of long stay persons and numerous aggravations, to facilitate the termination of residence of rejected asylum seekers, especially those from so-called "safe countries of origin"   asylum seekers are now obliged to present, surrender or leave with the authorities any relevant data carriers (mobile phones, tablets etc.). If they fail to do so authorities can order a search of him/her and the objects on His/her person. Access to the data must also be provided by the asylum applicant.
policies.notes: Reorganization of deportation law along the balance between private interests in staying and public interests in deportation.  Expulsion now requires a threat to public safety and order and a proportionality test that no longer leaves any room for discretion on the part of the foreigners authority

policies.policyName: Law for better enforcement on the obligation to leave the country
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz zur besseren Durchsetzung der Ausreisepflicht
policies.policyDescription: Expansion of the possibilities of detention pending deportation and residence monitoring (electronic ankle bracelet) for foreigners who are required to leave the country, especially for reasons of internal security. Possibility of spatial restriction of residence for tolerated persons who refuse to cooperate in removing obstacles to departure; abolition of one-month revocation period after more than one year of toleration for this group of persons; extension of maximum permissible duration of detention pending departure to 10 days; possibility of withholding foreign travel documents, including those of German citizens of multiple states; possibility of passing on specially protected data, especially from medical tests. Possibility for the BAMF to pass on protected data, especially from medical certificates, in order to avert danger; ex officio filing of asylum applications by youth welfare offices for unaccompanied foreign minors taken into care; introduction of the possibility to read mobile data carriers in the asylum procedure in order to secure, establish and verify the identity and nationality of asylum seekers; possibility to extend the time limit of the obligation for asylum seekers without prospects of remaining to live in initial reception facilities; restriction of fundamental rights relating to freedom of the person.

policies.policyName: Law on the extension of the suspension of family reunification with beneficiaries of subsidiary protection
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz zur Verlängerung der Aussetzung des Familiennachzuges zu subsidär Schutzberechtigten
policies.policyDescription: Prolongation of the suspension of family reunification with beneficiaries of subsidiary protection until the intended new regulation enters into force.

policies.policyName: Act on the Reorganization of Family Reunification with Beneficiaries of Subsidiary Protection (Family Reunification Reorganization Act)
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz zur Neuregelung des Familiennachzugs zu subsidär Schutzberechtigten (Familiennachzugsneuregelungsgesetz)
policies.policyDescription: Sec. 36a was integrated which regulates the family reunification for those entitled to susidiary protection   No legal entitlement of beneficiaries of subsidiary protection to family reunification, enabling family reunification with beneficiaries of subsidiary protection for humanitarian reasons, designation of important case groups, limitation of family reunification to members of the nuclear family and to 1,000 persons per month. 000 persons per month, consideration of integration aspects, definition of standard grounds for exclusion (marriage prior to flight, departure expected in the short term, existence of serious criminal acts), general refusal of family reunification with terrorist threats, hate preachers and leaders of banned associations; Inclusion of selfish instigation of or aiding and abetting the unauthorized entry of a minor unaccompanied as a qualifying criterion for the criminal offense of smuggling in foreigners; statistical recording of family reunification in the Central Register of Foreigners (AZR); restriction of fundamental rights relating to freedom of movement, postal and long-distance travel, and the right of residence. Restriction of Fundamental Rights with Respect to Freedom of Movement, Postal and Telecommunications Secrecy and Inviolability of the Home

policies.policyName: Law on toleration in training and employment
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz über Duldung bei Ausbildung und Beschäftigung
policies.policyDescription: Reorganization of the legal provisions on tolerated stay: Transfer of the previous regulation of the training toleration into a separate norm, concretization of essential prerequisites, inclusion of state-recognized assistant or helper training under the condition of subsequent qualified vocational training in a shortage occupation; creation of a thirty-month employment toleration with definition of clear criteria: Requirements to secure own livelihood, knowledge of German language, exemption from punishment and, if applicable, school attendance of children; grounds for refusal

policies.policyName: "Orderly Return Law", Second law to improve the enforcement of the obligation to leave the country
policies.originalPolicyName: Geordnete-Rückkehr-Gesetz Zweites Gesetz zur besseren Durchsetzung der Ausreisepflicht
policies.policyDescription: One of the amendments is the "Orderly Return Law" (Geordnete-Rückkehr-Gesetz), the second round of legal measures to facilitate deportations of persons obliged to leave the country, following a law passed in 2017.
policies.notes: "The bill facilitates the use of detention by expanding the grounds for using detention e.g. when asylum seekers  do not cooperate for the purpose of their deportation or in cases in which there is no evidence of a risk of absconding. Similarly, the authorities responsible for carrying out deportations are granted the right to access apartments without a judicial order in certain circumstances. In violation of the EU Return Directive, the bill also provides that, until 2022, people awaiting deportation may be placed in regular prisons as long as people affected will be held in premises separate from convicted criminals."Moreover, the length of stay in initial reception centres has been increased from 6 to 18 months as a general rule and to more than 18 months in certain circumstances (e.g. persons from safe countries of origin or persons who do not provide correct information on their identity).

policies.policyName: Act to postpone the census until 2022 and to amend the Residence Act
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz zur Verschiebung des Zensus in das Jahr 2022 und zur Änderung des Aufenthaltsgesetzes
policies.policyDescription: Introduction of the Sec. 62c on suppelmentary prepartory detention (ergänzende Vorbeirreitungshaft) in preparation for a deportation threat (Abschiebungsandrohung) for persons with an existing entry and residence ban, a threat to internal security or a particularly serious deportation interest
policies.notes: This amendment closes the regulatory gap in the cases where Sec. 62 III is not applicable, because the alien has applied for asylum (and is terefore allowed to stay in the country for the duration of the asylum procedure, i.e. there is no enforcable obligation to leave), in such cases Sec. 14 III Asylum Act would allow for the order or maintenance of detention, but rule requires that the alien is already in one of the types of detention or custody specified therein  -> therefore in the case where the asylum application is filled before the order for detention was filled Sec. 62c allows for order of detention

policies.policyName: Law on the introduction of an opportunity residence law
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz zur Einführung eines Chancen-Aufenthaltsrechts
policies.policyDescription: Amendment of Sec. 53 (Ausweisung)  a uniform designation standard for beneficiares of subsidiary protection, refugees and passport holders has now been formulated  the term "adolecent" has been changed to "young adult"
policies.notes: these designated persons can only be expelled if there are compelling reasons of national security or public order.

policies.policyName: Data Sharing Inprovement Act
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz zur Verbesserung der Registrierung und des Datenaustausches zu aufenthalts- und asylrechtlichhen Zwecken/Datenaustauschverbesserungsgesetz
policies.policyDescription: "Creation of a central core data system for the registration of asylum and protection seekers in the Central Register of Foreigners (AZR); addition of identification data, information on health examinations, vaccinations, qualifications, etc. to the basic personal data to be stored so far. Registration in the core data system upon first contact with the authorities, security comparison, obligation of all agencies authorized to register to transmit data to the Central Register of Foreigners, equipping the authorities with a fingerprint fast matching system (Fast-ID); authorization of public agencies to retrieve data from the core system within the scope of fulfilling their tasks; introduction of a certificate of registration as an asylum seeker ("proof of arrival"); authorization of the BAMF to transmit data stored in the Central Register of Foreigners to research institutions.  in regards to return this information is used to establish the identity of a refugee and therefore be able, in case of rejection, to issue travel documents/passports and to return him/her faster to their country of origin  Amendments to the residence Act: subsecion 8 and 9 -> third-country nationals who enterned unlawfully and still have to aquired a residence permit shall be documented in all cases (formally there were two preconditions to such a documentation, which have both been deleted) and the scope of documentation has also been expaned and now also includes potograps  Amendments to the asylum act: children under 14 y/o are now also subject to documentation, "prove of arrival" of all asylum seekers who have been photograped and fingerprinted, but have not yet filed an asyl application (nationwide standard)"

policies.policyName: Act on the introduction of accelerated asylum procedures (Asylum Package II)
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz zur Einführung beschleunigter Asylverfahren (Asylpaket II)
policies.policyDescription: The Asylum Package II would accelerate the asylum application process; suspend family reunification for refugees with subsidiary protection status for a period of two years; decrease asylees' monthly cash benefits; facilitate deportation; establish a new Federal Police unit to help procure replacement documents; improve the safety of refugee minors; and designate Algeria, Morocco, and Tunisia as safe countries of origin. (Kabinett beschliesst Asylpaket II. Schnellere Verfahren, weniger Familiennachzug [Cabinet Agrees on Asylum Package II. Faster Procedures, Less Family Reunification], German Federal Government website (Feb. 3, 2016).)
policies.notes: Facilitation of Deportation: Currently, refugees are able to prevent deportation by claiming they face medical problems and there is insufficient health care in their country of origin. According to the proposed rules, only serious or life-threatening diseases that could worsen because of the deportation will be taken into account. The seriousness of the disease would have to be demonstrated by a medical certificate from an accredited medical practitioner. The fact that the available medical care is not comparable to that found in Germany would not be a sufficient reason in itself to prevent the deportation. (Kabinett beschliesst Asylpaket II, supra.)

policies.policyName: Act to Facilitate the Expulsion of Aliens with Criminal Records and to Expand the Exclusion of Refugee Recognition in the Case of Asylum Seekers with Criminal Records
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz zur erleichterten Ausweisung von straffälligen Ausländern und zur erweiterten Ausschluss der Flüchtlingsanerkennung bei straffälligen Asylberwerben
policies.policyDescription: When foreigners seeking protection in Germany under asylum procedures or staying in Germany for other reasons commit crimes on a significant scale, this can jeopardize social peace in Germany and acceptance by the local population for the reception of those in need of protection and for legal immigration. In addition, events such as those on New Year's Eve 2015/2016 foster resentment toward foreigners and asylum seekers who behave lawfully here.  The aim of the regulations is therefore to facilitate the expulsion of criminal foreigners and to deny asylum seekers who commit crimes legal recognition as refugees more consistently than before.
policies.notes: added in Sec. 53(2) the "fact whether the foreigner has behaved lawfully" to the considerations mentioned there and tightened the interests of expulsion mentioned in Sec. 54.

policies.policyName: Basic Law Germany (Art. 16a)
policies.originalPolicyName: Grundgesetz (Art. 16a)
policies.policyDescription: "Amendment of the Art. 16a Basic Law -> concept of ""safe thrid counrty"" was implemented in the consitution   German consitution defines as safe countries of origin the countries 'in which, on the basis of their laws, enforcement practices and general political conditions, it can be safely concluded that neither political persecution nor inhuman or degrading punishment or treatment exists'."
policies.notes: right to asylum, except for third countries considered safe (definition in Art. 16(3))

policies.policyName: Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act
policies.originalPolicyName: Asylbewerberleistungsgesetz
policies.policyDescription: regulates the benefits asylum seekers are entitled to, while their application is being processed, when they are abliged to leave or during temporary suspension of removal  Benefits may be reduced, stopped or resticted when the application refuses to leave
policies.notes: Sec. 1a  is not a strict rule on removal, but may increase the chances of voluntaryreturn

policies.policyName: Law on Return Assistance
policies.originalPolicyName: Rückkehrhilfegesetz
policies.policyDescription: "Reduction of obstacles to return, targeted return assistance, redemption of individual claims while avoiding deadweight effects, time limits   Applications for return assistance could be filed until June 30, 1984. After the expiration of this deadline, the law no longer had any practical significance with regard to financial benefits. However, it is still in force today and gives foreigners interested in returning, regardless of nationality, a legal right to counseling from the Federal Employment Agency (Sec. 7 Law on Return assisstance). "
policies.notes: This law has no longer any real effect on assisted retrun of migrants today.

policies.policyName: Guideline for nationwide return counselling
policies.originalPolicyName: Leitlinie für eine bundesweites Rückkehrberatung
policies.policyDescription: "To ensure a uniform standard in return counselling, to increase volunary return a the primary form of return   sets framework conditions and quality standards of the counselling "

policies.policyName: Act on the General Freedom of Movement for EU Citiztens
policies.originalPolicyName: Freizügigkeitsgesetz/EU
policies.policyDescription: Fundamental restructuring of the right of residence, including. Limiting immigration, reducing the number of residence titles to two: (temporary) residence permit and (permanent) settlement permit, flexible management of immigration for employment reasons, attractive residence conditions for students and highly qualified persons, regulations on the relocation of ethnic German immigrants, promotion of the integration of immigrants, in particular through language courses, limitation of the age at which children can join their parents to 12 years, new regulations on the admission and granting of rights of residence for humanitarian reasons, Acceleration of the implementation of asylum recognition procedures and the return of persons who are obliged to leave the country, financial participation of foreigners in the costs of integration courses, application of the Geneva Refugee Convention in cases of non-governmental and gender-specific persecution, identity-securing measures in the visa procedure, improved data collection and transmission; independent regulation of the right of entry and residence of Union citizens and their family members
policies.notes: when the right to stay or entry no longer applies to a person they are obliged to leave and will, if necessary, be forcefully removed Sec. 7   since this law also applies to non-EU citizens they also can be removed or ordered to leave based on this law

policies.policyName: Nationality Act
policies.originalPolicyName: Staatsangehörigkeitsgesetz/StAG
policies.policyDescription: "Acquisistion and neutralisation of the German nationality, also regulates the loss of citizenship   Sec. 7 StAG is the relevant provosion for the late resettlers returning to Germany "

policies.policyName: Central Register of foreigners Act
policies.originalPolicyName: Gesetz über das Ausländerzentralregister (AZRG)
policies.policyDescription: Law regarding the Central register for foreigner, which collects data about foreigners, who not only temporarily are staying or have stayed in Germany. Regulates the Responsibilties, Content and Procedure for the storage and sharing of the relevant data.

policies.policyName: Regulation on the revision of the Asylum Responsibility Determination Regulation
policies.originalPolicyName: Verordnung zur Neufassung der Asylzuständigkeitsbestimmungsverordnung
policies.policyDescription: Formal transfer of responsibility for the implementation of the Dublin Convention procedure to the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees and the border authorities

policies.policyName: General administrative Regulation to the Residence Act
policies.originalPolicyName: Allgemeine Verwaltungsvorschrift zum Aufenthaltsgesetz (AVwVAufenthG)
policies.policyDescription: this is an order of the Federal Ministry of the interior and contains Instructions on the application and interpretation of the Residence Act

policies.policyDescription: Instrctions regarding the asylum procedure

policies.originalPolicyName: Dienstanweisung Asyl
policies.policyDescription: "Instructions regarding the asylum procdure drawn up by the BAMF to standardize decision-making practice under asylum law at all locations nationwide   including information about the procedure and comments on the substantive asylum law

policies.policyName: Dublin Instructions

policies.policyName: The Aliens Act (SFS 2005:716)
policies.originalPolicyName: Utlänningslag (SFS 2005:716)
policies.policyDescription: The Aliens Act is the primary piece of legislation regulating migration to Sweden. This Act includes definitions, general regulations, and conditions that must be met for foreigners to be allowed entry, residence, and employment in Sweden. It also encompasses regulations on detention, the enforcement of decisions regarding residence permits, the appeals process, and so on.
policies.notes: Announced in 2005 (entry into force 2006)

policies.policyName: The Aliens Ordinance (SFS 2006:97)
policies.originalPolicyName: Utlänningsförordning (SFS 2006:97)
policies.policyDescription: The Aliens Ordinance contains supplementary and, in some cases, more detailed regulations that complement the Aliens Act

policies.policyName: Act (2022:700) on special control of certain foreigners
policies.originalPolicyName: Lag (2022:700) om särskild kontroll av vissa utlänningar
policies.policyDescription: The Act specifies the conditions under which a foreign national can be expelled on grounds of national security or if there is reasonable suspicion that they will engage in or participate in terrorist activities. It applies exclusively to individuals currently in Sweden who are not subject to deportation or expulsion under the provisions of the Aliens Act.

policies.policyName: The Act on residence permits for students at upper secondary level (2017:353)
policies.originalPolicyName: Lag (2017:353) om uppehållstillstånd för studerande på gymnasial nivå
policies.policyDescription: The act contains special provisions on residence permits for students at upper secondary school level.
policies.notes: Some parts of the law expired in December 2023, others will apply until 2024 or, at the latest, January 1 2025 (when the law expires as a whole).

policies.policyName: The Administrative Procedure Act (2017:900)
policies.originalPolicyName: Förvaltningslag (2017:900)
policies.policyDescription: The Act is a framework Act on administrative procedure which applies when the Aliens Act does not contain specific provisions.

policies.policyName: The temporary Act (2016:752) on temporary restrictions on the possibility of obtaining residence permits in Sweden.
policies.originalPolicyName: den tillfälliga lagen (Lag (2016:752) om tillfälliga begränsningar av möjligheten att få uppehållstillstånd i Sverige
policies.policyDescription: The temporary law was introduced in connection with the refugee situation in 2015 with the aim of reducing asylum immigration to Sweden. Through the restrictions that were introduced, Sweden's asylum rules were lowered to the minimum level required by EU law and international conventions.2 After the temporary law was introduced in July 2016, the number of asylum seekers coming to Sweden has decreased. In 2017, approximately 26,000 asylum seekers came to Sweden, compared to the refugee situation in 2015, when just under 163,000 people sought asylum.

policies.policyName: The Unaccompanied Minors Guardian Act (2005:429)
policies.originalPolicyName: Lag (2005:429) om god man för ensamkommande barn
policies.policyDescription: The Act contains provisions on the appointment of a guardian for unaccompanied minors (foreign citizens and stateless persons).

policies.policyName: Reception of Asylum Seekers Act (LMA) (1994:137)
policies.originalPolicyName: Lag (1994:137) om mottagande av asylsökande m.fl. (LMA)
policies.policyDescription: The Act contains regulations on housing, social benefits, occupation such as language courses or other activites (not employment) etc. for asylum seekers, persons who have applied for temporary protection, and in special cases.

policies.policyName: Act on health care for asylum seekers and others. (2008:344)
policies.originalPolicyName: Lag (2008:344) om hälso- och sjukvård åt asylsökande m.fl.
policies.policyDescription: The Act contains supplementary regulations regarding the obligations of the regions to provide health care and dental care to asylum seekers, holders of temporary protection permits and persons held  in detention. It also applies to rejected asylum seekers, but not those who are actively avoiding enforcement of a negative asylum decision. The extent of access to health care varies between children and adults.

policies.policyName: Ordinance on Reception of Asylum Seekers and others (1994:361)
policies.originalPolicyName: Förordning (1994:361) om mottagande av asylsökande m.fl.
policies.policyDescription: The Ordinance contains additional regulations on housing, benefits etc. for asylum seekers and others.

policies.policyName: Ordinance on health care for asylum seekers etc. (2008:347)
policies.originalPolicyName: Förordning (2008:347) om hälso- och sjukvård åt asylsökande m.fl.
policies.policyDescription: The Ordinance establishes that the Swedish Migration Agency must provide information to regions about persons covered by the Act on health care for asylum seekers and others and the manner in which this is to be carried out.

policies.policyName: Ordinance on state compensation for healthcare for asylum seekers. (1996:1357)
policies.originalPolicyName: Förordning (1996:1357) om statlig ersättning för hälso- och sjukvård till asylsökande
policies.policyDescription: The Ordinance contains provisions on financial compensation to regions for healthcare costs including costs for dental care, as well as to pharmacies for prescription drugs.

policies.policyName: Ordinance on re-establishment support for certain foreigners (2008:778)
policies.originalPolicyName: Förordning (2008:778) om återetableringsstöd för vissa utlänningar
policies.policyDescription: The Ordinance regulates access to financial support to aliens having applied for international protection in case of their voluntaryreturn.

policies.policyName: Act (2021:1187) with supplementary provisions to the EU's regulations on the Schengen Information System.
policies.originalPolicyName: Lag (2021:1187) med kompletterande bestämmelser till EU:s förordningar om Schengens informationssystem
policies.policyDescription: This regulation supplements- Regulation (EU) 2018/1860 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 28 November 2018 on the use of the Schengen Information System for the return of third-country nationals staying illegally in the Member States, here referred to as the Return Regulation,      - Regulation (EU) 2018/1861 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 28 November 2018 on the establishment, operation and use of the Schengen Information System (SIS) in the field of entry and exit controls, amending the Convention on the application of the Schengen Agreement
policies.notes: The act was announced in 2021 (entry into force 2023)

policies.policyName: The Detention Act (2010:611)
policies.originalPolicyName: Häkteslag (2010:611)
policies.policyDescription: The Act contains fundamental provisions persons on respect for human dignity held in detention in policy custody premises instead of in Migration Agency detention centres.

policies.policyName: The Act of Judicial Procedure (RB 1942:740)
policies.originalPolicyName: Rättegångsbalk (1942:740)
policies.policyDescription: The Swedish Code of Judicial Procedure is presented under the topics of court organization, judicial proceedings in general, evidence, lower court proceedings, appellate proceedings, supreme court proceedings, and extraordinary remedies for substantive defects and grave procedural errors.

policies.policyName: Act (2018:1693) on the police's processing of personal data within the scope of the Criminal Data Act
policies.originalPolicyName: Lag (2018:1693) om polisens behandling av personuppgifter inom brottsdatalagens område
policies.policyDescription: The law shall apply to the processing of personal data related to national security in the Swedish Security Service's crime-fighting and prosecution activities. When the Swedish Security Service processes personal data that do not pertain to national security for the purpose of combating and prosecuting crimes, the authority shall apply the Crime Data Act and the Police Data Act. Furthermore, consequential amendments are proposed in several other laws.

policies.policyName: Adaptations of Swedish law to the EU regulations on the Schengen Information System 2020/21:222
policies.originalPolicyName: Anpassningar av svensk lag till EU:s förordningar om Schengens informationssystem 2020/21:222
policies.policyDescription: The government proposes the repeal of the Schengen Information System Act (2000:344) and its replacement with a new law containing supplementary provisions for the EU regulations on the Schengen Information System. Furthermore, changes are proposed in the Aliens Act (2005:716), the Freedom of the Press and Secrecy Act (2009:400), the Aliens Data Act (2016:27), and the Act (2018:1693) on the Police's Processing of Personal Data within the Crime Data Act's scope.
policies.notes: announced year 2020

policies.policyName: Adaptation of Swedish law to the new EU travel data and authorisation system 2022/23:66
policies.originalPolicyName: Anpassning av svensk rätt till EU:s nya system för reseuppgifter och resetillstånd 2022/23:66
policies.policyDescription: The system aims to enable an assessment of whether a third-country national's stay on the territory of the member states would pose a security risk, a risk of illegal immigration, or a high epidemiological risk. Additionally, the system aims, among other things, to enhance and streamline entry and exit controls at the external borders. policies.policyName: Amended provisions on photographs and fingerprints in the SIS II legal frameworkProp. 2020/21:6
policies.originalPolicyName: Ändrade bestämmelser om fotografier och fingeravtryck i SIS II-regelverketProp. 2020/21:6
policies.policyDescription: The government proposes changes to the Schengen Information System Act and the Aliens Act, which include that a foreign national, during an entry or exit check or an internal alien control, shall be obligated to be photographed and provide fingerprints to be able to be identified through a search in the Schengen Information System if their identity cannot be established in any other way. The proposals are made in light of amendments to Council Decision 2007/533/EC of June 12, 2007, on the establishment, operation, and use of the second generation of the Schengen Information System (SIS II), and Regulation (EC) No 1987/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of December 20, 2006, on the establishment, operation, and use of the second generation of the Schengen Information System (SIS II).

policies.policyName: Adaptation of the Aliens Data Act to the EU Data Protection Regulation Prop. 2017/18:254
policies.originalPolicyName: Anpassning av utlänningsdatalagen till EU:s dataskyddsförordningProp. 2017/18:254
policies.policyDescription: The regulation, which will come into force on 25 May 2018, is directly applicable in Sweden. However, Swedish constitutions need to be adapted to ensure that the regulation has an effective impact and that Swedish law does not conflict with the regulation.The proposals mean, among other things, that the references to the Personal Data Act are repealed and that certain provisions are supplemented with references to the regulation. The government also proposes changes regarding the Aliens Data Act's relationship to other legislation and the design of the ban on privacy-sensitive searches. Certain exceptions to the regulation's provisions are also proposed.

policies.policyName: Modern and legally secure rules for keeping foreigners in custody prop. 2017/18:284
policies.originalPolicyName: Moderna och rättssäkra regler för att hålla utlänningar i förvar Prop. 2017/18:284
policies.policyDescription: The proposed rules mean, among other things, that a court must always consider whether an alien may be detained for longer than two weeks with the support of the Aliens Act, the principle of proportionality takes on a decisive importance when assessing how long a foreigner may be kept in custody, it becomes clearer which authority is responsible at each stage of the migration process for deciding on detention or supervision, and the individual receives an extended right to speak orally before the administrative authorities and the migration courts. The government also proposes that a decision on rejection or expulsion not must be enforced if the alien is suspected of a crime punishable by imprisonment in the penalty scale, or if proceedings have been initiated for the alien to be extradited or handed over to another state to be prosecuted or to serve a custodial sentence. It is also proposed that in some cases it should be possible to close a preliminary investigation against a foreigner who is suspected of a crime with a penalty value that is not judged to exceed imprisonment for six months.

policies.policyName: EU border code Prop. 2014/15:32
policies.originalPolicyName: EU:s gränskodexProp. 2014/15:32
policies.policyDescription: Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council on a Community Code on the rules governing the movement of persons across borders (the Border Code) is directly applicable in Sweden. The proposal in this bill suggests amendments to the Aliens Act that are motivated by the Border Code. These amendments involve the repeal of certain provisions regarding border crossings in the Aliens Act and the addition of references to the code in other sections. Furthermore, it is proposed that the Aliens Act be supplemented with a provision on the obligation to provide fingerprints in situations as stipulated by the Border Code. The bill also includes proposals for some other amendments to the Aliens Act. These amendments concern, among other things, the provisions regarding deferred immigration assessment in cases of residence permits based on family ties.

policies.policyName: More effective tools for internal alien control Prop. 2023/24:12
policies.originalPolicyName: Effektivare verktyg vid inre utlänningskontrollProp. 2023/24:12
policies.policyDescription: The Swedish government has also proposed in another bill (2023/24:12) the introduction of the authority for officials to perform a body search on a foreign national during an internal immigration control in order to search for passports or other identity documents, as well as the authority to confiscate such documents. Additionally, it is suggested to provide clarity that, under specific circumstances, a foreign national may be detained for an investigation regarding their right to reside in Sweden. The legislative changes outlined in this bill are slated to come into effect in the upcoming year 2024 ( Government bill, 2023/24:12,p1).

policies.policyName: Follow-up of the return directive and the directive on the status of long-term resident third-country nationals
policies.originalPolicyName: Uppföljning av återvändandedirektivet och direktivet om varaktigt bosatta tredjelandsmedborgares ställning
policies.policyDescription: Concerning the Return Directive, a new provision is proposed for the examination of the question of expulsion or deportation of a non-EEA national who holds a residence permit in another EU state and who is not a family member of an EEA national. The provision implies that such a foreign national, with some exceptions, should be encouraged to voluntarily travel to the other EU state within a reasonable time, and expulsion or deportation may only be decided if such encouragement is not followed. Furthermore, changes are proposed, among other things, to the rules on appealing against the Police Authority's decisions regarding entry bans to avoid situations where closely related matters are handled by different appellate authorities. Regarding the Directive on Long-Term Residents, it is proposed that the requirement for permanent residence permits no longer be a prerequisite for obtaining long-term resident status in Sweden.

policies.policyName: Implementation of the Return Directive Prop. 2011/12:60
policies.originalPolicyName: Genomförande av återvändandedirektivetProp. 2011/12:60
policies.policyDescription: The proposal in the bill is for the implementation of Directive 2008/115/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of December 16, 2008, on common standards and procedures in Member States for returning illegally staying third-country nationals (the Return Directive). It is proposed that, as a general rule, a decision of expulsion or deportation should include a voluntary departure period. The voluntary departure period should be set at two weeks for expulsion and four weeks for deportation. If it is not possible to grant a voluntary departure period, a decision of expulsion or deportation should normally be accompanied by a re-entry ban for a maximum duration of five years. A re-entry ban should generally also be imposed on a foreign national who has been granted a voluntary departure period but has not left the country by the end of the specified period. In such cases, the re-entry ban should be set for one year. A re-entry ban may be revoked if there are specific reasons for no longer enforcing the ban.

policies.policyName: Ministry of Interior Regulation No 29656 on the Fight against Human Trafficking and Protection of Victims
policies.originalPolicyName: İnsan Ticaretiyle Mücadele ve Mağdurların Korunması Hakkında Yönetmelik
policies.policyDescription: It outlines the regulation concerning the protection and assistance of foreign victims of human trafficking. This comprehensive regulation includes various measures to ensure the safety, health, and welfare of victims. Below is an overview of the key points covered in the document:    Identification of Victims: The regulation mandates the prompt identification of potential or confirmed victims of human trafficking. It stresses on the confidentiality of victims' personal data and the protection of their identity throughout the process​​.    Sheltering and Accommodation: Victims are to be placed in shelters run by the PMM or, if that's not possible, in public institutions, local administrations, or NGO-run shelters. The location of these shelters is kept confidential for safety reasons, and all parties involved are required to adhere to these confidentiality rules​.    Support and Care for Victims: The regulation details a victim support program that includes shelter, health services access, psychological support, social services, legal aid, education, vocational training, and temporary financial support, among other services. Victims can receive these services during the reflection period, investigation, prosecution phases, and beyond​​.    Termination of Support: The support program can be terminated if the victim chooses not to participate, reconnects with perpetrators, leaves the shelter without notice, fails to comply with the program measures, does not cooperate with authorities, or is found to have provided false information​​.    Voluntary and Safe Return Program: The regulation also provides for a voluntary and safe return program for victims who choose not to take advantage of the support program or wish to return to their home country or a third country after the program ends. This includes arrangements for safe travel and necessary protection measures​​.    Administrative and Legal Provisions: The regulation gives the Directorate the authority to make administrative arrangements for the implementation of these rules, and it states that these provisions are executed by the Ministry of Interior​.

policies.policyName: Regulation on Alternatives to Administrative Detention

policies.policyDescription: New amendments to the law in December 2019 included Article 57(A) LFIP, which lays down alternatives to pre-removal. The measures are:  a) Residence at a specific address b) Notification c) Family-based repatriation ç) Return consultancy d) Working on a voluntary basis in public benefit services e) Guarantee f) Electronic monitoring. In September 2022, implementing regulation on alternative measures entered into force. The regulation establishes the possibility to apply measures that do not limit or restrict their freedom in substitution of administrative detention to an individual who was issued a deportation order. These measures shall not be applied for more than 24-months and non-compliance shall be a ground for imposing pre-removal detention. According to the regulation, alternatives can be applied to these groups of people:   - Persons whose administrative detention has been terminated;  - Persons deemed suitable for alternative duty/duties without a decision of administrative detention;  - Persons whose administrative detention has been terminated as a result of an assessment conducted by the PMM or the relevant governorate; - Persons whose administrative detention was terminated through the decision of the governorate based on the ruling of a magistrate court.  These individuals are ineligible for an alternative-to-detention determination.  - Persons who face a significant risk of persecution in their country of origin;  - Persons who are at risk of travelling due to severe health issues, age, or pregnancy; - Individuals receiving treatment for life-threatening diseases;  - Victims of human trafficking who benefit from the victim support process;  - Victims of psychological, physical, or sexual violence until their treatment is completed.

policies.policyName: Immigration Act 2016
policies.originalPolicyName: Immigration Act 2016
policies.policyDescription: The Immigration Act 2016 marked a comprehensive overhaul of immigration policies, encompassing measures to enhance enforcement, combat illegal activities, and streamline processes. It granted increased powers to immigration officers, introducing offenses related to illegal working and sham marriages. The act mandated landlords to conduct right-to-rent checks on prospective tenants and implemented penalties for non-compliance. Additionally, it focused on supporting victims of modern slavery and trafficking, improving identification and assistance services. Changes to the immigration bail system, restrictions on certain appeals, and the introduction of the Immigration Skills Charge for skilled worker sponsors were also pivotal aspects. Overall, the act aimed to address diverse challenges in the immigration system, aiming for a more controlled and responsive framework
